animalOfTheDay.name: zebu
facts: Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.
Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.
Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.
Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.

calendar.name: wren
facts: Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.
They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.

calendar.name: yak
facts: Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.
Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.

randomAnimals.name: owl
facts: Their asymmetrical ears help them pinpoint the exact location of prey in complete darkness.
Owls are silent fliers, thanks to specialized feathers that muffle sound.
Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees due to specialized vertebrae.
They swallow prey whole and later regurgitate indigestible parts as pellets.

randomAnimals.name: zonkey
facts: Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.

randomAnimals.name: ring-tailed lemur
facts: Ring-tailed lemurs are the most recognizable lemur species, known for their long, ringed tail with black and white bands.
They live in large social groups called 'troops,' and females dominate males.
Their tails are longer than their bodies and serve for balance and communication.
Unlike most lemurs, ring-tailed lemurs spend a lot of time on the ground, basking in the sun with their arms spread out.
